title: Is American exceptionalism out of step with reality? - Quora
tags: Culture of the United States of America
Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Depends on what one means by this term. Some use it positively and some negatively, but I think these days it is used to mean the idea that the US is unique among nations and that therefore our history, motives, etc. cannot be compared to those of other nations. The issue is complex. In some ways, the US is different from most other nations— both better and worse. To get some ideas of how different aspects of American exceptionalism play out in positive and negative ways, I trecommend Seymour Martin Lipsett’s “American Exceptionalism.” Lipsett posits these aspects of “Americanism”: liberty, egalitarianism, individualism, republicanism, democracy, and laissez-faire economics. He then discusses good and bad aspects of each. The book is obviously more complex than this, but it provides a useful context for discussing this term.

Are there any other people, in any other country, that have inalienable right? Are there any other people, in any other country, that have the right and responsibility to kill tyrants when and/or where they show up? If that is not American exceptionalism, then what is? 22 million American veterans have swore oaths to the Constitution, not the government. And another 70 million armed Americans that are not veterans, but believe in the same. That exceptional.
